when i walked into my lhs which has a large off road track, i asked the guy behind the counter about what would be fun to run behind my house and competitive at the track.
being a newbie to the rc world i wasnt looking to spend alot of money.
they had some less expensive short course trucks and naturally asked about them first.
he told me if i was just looking to bash in the backyard the 200$ sc they sold would be a great truck, if i was looking to race then the team associated sc10rs would be a better choice.
the guy said he been doing rc for 30 years.
i asked if i bought this could i just drop it on the track and be competitive?
he assured me i could.
my brother and i both bought this truck that day, his the rock starmakita version mine this very toyota.
we raced with them stock a week later and even though we were complete noobs we still placed better than last against guys running hopped up losis and 200$ transmitters.
after some rigorous practice and new tires that better fit the track, im now running mid pack, slowly moving up every week, well my brother has taken 2 first place finishes in the 3 weeks weve raced.
im confident with time ill be in the front of the pack and my truck is not what is holding me back.
i catch everyone in the straight and can turn as tight as anything out there.
i run 5300ma 40c lipo batteries.
i recommend at least 40 c battery as this car definitely shows an improvement in punch on the 40c over a 30c battery.
running less than a 30c battery will overstress the battery and definitely effect performance.
the guy at the shop said more than a 40c battery wont show a performance boost or a very negligible one.
sounds believable since he make more if he sold me a more expensive higher c battery.
as far as durability is concerned ive smashed this thing in every way conceivable.
i did manage to rip the rear a arm off after about 4 weeks of running this thing to the hilt, and the lexon body cracked alot in the rear, but some gorilla tape fixed that right up.
the rear a arms at my local track were only 7$ a set for the oem ones.
besides that this thing has taken a beating and kept going.
ive cycled multiple batteries through it in a row with out cool down time.
the motor hasnt shown any loss of performance.
i try to let it cool down now between runs since talking to experienced guys who told me running more than 10 minutes straight can damage a rc motor.
the 5300ma lipos batteries last easily 20 minutes running close to wide open or wide open about 50 of the time on the track.
the battery cut off has always left 6 volts in my pack.

i definitely wouldnt want to run them any lower since everything ive read online says 6v is ok but theirs alot of debate about anything lower and most agree its probably damaging your pack going lower.
the stock shell does suffer from "parachuting" when going off large jumps.
since the track i run on is set up for 18 buggy and truggy both electric and nitro the jumps are huge.
you can hit most of them but it takes precise lining up and getting hard on the throttle as soon as possible.
the truck is light enough that even though its only rear wheel drive you do have a fair amount of control using the throttle and brake to adjust your angle mid air.
assuming that a strong wind doesnt come along and flip you over mid air or cause you too levitate.
from what ive seen everyone either cuts holes in their body or most just use flo tech bodies to negate this issue.
the stock body seems fine as long as its not windy, it is very predictable.
at the last race i went to it had rained hard for a few hours prior to race start.
the track was muddy and not just regular mud but muddy clay.

durring qualifying my truck started having serious performance issues and at one point i watched it come through a left turn and as it rolled out i noticed the front left wheel dipped deep into the chassis at the apex of the corner.
i thought i had blown a shock.
after the race i picked up my car and it weighed nearly twice its normal weight.
the entire inside of the shell and the rest of the truck from the rear end through the front suspension was caked in mud.
the fan on the esc was even burried and not spinning.
well i cleaned it out with brushs the best i could but i still felt it was heavier than it should be.
the fan came back to life though.
on my 2nd race i noticed it still was not performing as well as it should and caked up again before it was over.
so this time i just took it over to the hose and sprayed the whole truck out.
yeah im nuts, but you know what i let it dry till the next heat, popped a battery in it and it still worked like nothing happened.
i took care not to spray directly into seals on the rear end, electronics, and survo.
im not saying that you should hose your car right out like i did but i am saying that i did it and the car didnt skip a beat.
i cant say that i have alot of experience with short course trucks, the only other truck i have is a hpi blitz that i got a great deal on used.
i can tell you though from my experience this sc10rs has hop ups from the factory that are needed and none that it doesnt.
it has aluminum shocks and a brushless motor which everyone agrees if you have a standard sc10 are 2 of the first things you should get.
the survo in it is also fairly strong, and quick.
its not the most amazing thing you can buy but from what ive learned from other sc guys is it is the best survo that comes in any brand sc rtr.
also the transmitter, will not a 100$ or 200$ unit does feel smooth and has all the adjustment knobs you need.
mine came with the new style with the knobs on top so did my brothers.
also like i said earlier, my brother is running this thing full stock minus tires and that includes the transmitter and is laying a hurting on guys with mush more expensive equipment.
the only downside ive really seen with this truck is its transmission is loud compared to the blitz which hasfull metal gears and is filled with gear oil.
the sc10s gears are mostly plastic and only runs a semi sealed designed.
i dont believe this was done to save cost.
the blitz weighs considerably more because of that full metal tranny which effects everything from acceleration to how will it jumps.
ive had zero problems with the rear end in the sc10 and i beat on it as hard as i want.
so plastic gears or not they hold up well.
this is just a well built racer using metal only where it is absolutely crucial for durability.
the only thing i upgraded were the wheel hexes in the back to aluminum ones.
i chewed up my plastic ones running with the wheels lose and not realizing it.
they also make wheel changing easier cause they lock onto the axle where as the plastic ones were only held in place by the wheel and tended to get stuck in the rim when the wheel was removed.
its a hop up for convenience more than anything and adds very little weight.
oh and i should mention the esc will come loose on you if you run this thing hard as you should.
the factory applied double sided tape is garbage.
we bought scotch brand double sided outdoor rated tape and nothing has broken loose since.
we also use it for our transponders.
get that and some gorrilla tape for reinforcing the shell if it cracks and youll be all set.

a really great game, easy to play and teach though it may seem daunting at first glance, its really not.
also, inexpensive as games go, at least until you start going for all the expansion sets.

the base game is a good solid start thatll keep you playing for quite a while, since there are 25 &34kingdom&34 cards from which you use only 10 per game, so the number of variations is pretty good.the thing to note about dominion is, depending on what kingdom cards are in a given game, sets the stage for the strategy.
different strategies work in most cases, but part of the game is figuring out what will be the best strategy to choose given what kingdom cards are available to buy in that particular game.
this also increases the replay value since you wont always be using the exact same strategy every game.

and picking combinations of kingdom cards to play that work together to give you extra benefits is really fun to pull off.dont let the massive number of cards intimidate you the core part of the game of the kingdom cards, youre only using 10 at a time, though therell be a bunch of copies of each which makes it look a lot more complex than it really is.

i taught it to a friend who within a couple of turns had it figured out and she ended up beating me using a kingdom card that i had been previously ignoring because it didnt seem that powerful the cellar she saw the value of it where i didnt and ended up winning.
a very fun game.
if in doubt, try the online version, you can play the base game for free.one thing to note the base game will play 24. and as a 2player its excellent.
you can go up to 8 players by combining the original set with intrigue but i hear when going over 4 players it tends to bog down somewhat.

i bought intrigue because we do have 5 in our game group now and then, but havent had a chance yet to figure out how good it is with 5, ill probably try it but with a group of more than 5id probably either divide them up into two games also possible with the intrigue set, or even just by adding the basecard set.all in all, a totally awesome game.

these air hogs smash bots were put the test by my 9 year old daughter and then her 13 year old brother had to jump in to challenge her.
the concept sounds cool, the reality ok but not quite as cool.first off  10 aaa batteries required between the 2 sets of robotscontrollers batteries not included.
thats alot of aaa batteries  to appease the angry mob i was able to scrounge up enough aaas after cannibalizing various devices around the house.
once batteries loaded and units operational my kids headed into battle.
basically the remote controllers let you have your robot spin its arms to the left or the right  the turbo wheel makes them spin faster.
no walking function except the spinning does cause the robot to creep around the floor  spin away and try and knock the other robot over.
for whatever reason my daughter seemed to win more often than her big bro as expected he blamed his robot as being inferior.

i was actually impressed with build quality  rugged plastic beefed up to better survive physical combat.what could be better remote controls have weak signal and the kids needed to be within a few feet of the robots to consistently control the robots.
replayability  my kids got pretty bored of this pretty fast  they quit playing after an hour and havent tried again since.
thus im going to say ideal ages are younger than 9. functionality  would be more fun to have more controllable features on the robots  some type of controllable mobility.

perhaps a nerf rocket you could launch remotely.in summary  good build quality, takes too many batteries, limited ability to control robots, replayability probably best for kids under 9. at $50 current price kinda pricey considering all these factors though around the same price of a new release video game if you think of it that way  overall rating from me is 3stars in consideration of pricevalue.
keychain arrived very quickly10 days after purchase, and is of good quality.

the keychain itself is of fantastic quality though, made of a solid metal.halderthe companys name is embedded on the charms backs, which are unpainted.
the characters themselves look fantastic, and the only minor complaint i have is that polnareffs tanktop is pink on the keychain, when in the show its a dark blueblack.
other than that, its a solid 5 stars.

there is a supply of paper and some markets for preparing a book.
once complete, the drawings are sent to crayola who return one hardcover book with additional copies available to order.
its a fun way summer project and way to get kids thinking about how to frame and tell a story.
there is a limited number of pages so some parental help is advisable in setting up the story, especially for older kids who may want to tell a longer story.
my own kid stalled out a bit in writing.
the idea of having a finished, printed book does lead to a lot more thinking about what should go in there.
it may require some extra guidance but its a great project that inspires a ton of creativity.

the police range rover arrived broken for me, and it honestly took me a bit to care to fix it without having to return it.

the problem was the motor was improperly set when it was manufactured so i had to put it back into place and snap the plastic housing that holds it together to spin a wheel.after that was all said and done, this toy takes 3xaa batteries to power some lights and a motor to have the car drive, bump into something then change directions to bump into something else.
the police siren is loud and the toy itself is pretty simple.
im disappointed in this specific car as it looks pretty cheap and seems overpriced at $30.
i recently reviewed another techege police toy that transformed and that at least did something more interesting where my daughter enjoyed playing with it.

this toy does not drive on carpet well so unless you have mostly hardwoodtile floors you wont get much out of it.i received this complimentary free police range rover for testing and my unbiased and honest review.
